Interpolation on n-dimensional grid impossible through scipy.interpolate.griddata,"

I think the problem is that you need to make sure you're consistent about the number of dimensions, and the 'domains' of those dimensions. You won't get good results interpolating into places you have not sampled. I think the errors you're getting are related to trying to compute things in these places.

Here's how to make something like the example in the scipy.interpolate.griddata docs work for a 7-dimensional example. I'm using a much simpler function which just sums the 'features' in the points data:

Notice that the grid covers the entire range of the coordinates points. That is, since each column in points has values in the range 0 to 1, I should make sure I'm making a grid over those same coordinates.
array([[ nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan],

Notice that there are a lot of NaNs. If you use nearest as the method, you'll always get a solution, but of course linear interpolation needs two things to interpolate between, so the 'edges' of the hypercube are not valid (and 7-D space has a lot of edge!).
,Challenges in using scipy.interpolate.griddata for n-dimensional grid interpolation,
Challenges in using scipy.interpolate.griddata for n-dimensional grid interpolation

I think the problem is that you need to make sure you're consistent about the number of dimensions, and the 'domains' of those dimensions. You won't get good results interpolating into places you have not sampled. I think the errors you're getting are related to trying to compute things in these places. Here's how to make something like the example in the scipy.interpolate.griddata docs work for a 7-dimensional example. I'm using a much simpler function which just sums the 'features' in the points data: import numpy as np def func(data): return np.sum(data, axis=1) grid = np.mgrid[0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j] points = np.random.rand(100, 7) values = func(points) Notice that the grid covers the entire range of the coordinates points. That is, since each column in points has values in the range 0 to 1, I should make sure I'm making a grid over those same coordinates. from scipy.interpolate import griddata grid_z = griddata(points, values, tuple(grid), method='linear') Now I have this: >>> grid_z[2, 2, 2, 2, 2, :, :] array([[ nan, nan, nan, nan, nan], [ nan, 3. , 3.25, 3.5 , nan], [ nan, 3.25, 3.5 , 3.75, nan], [ nan, 3.5 , 3.75, 4. , nan], [ nan, nan, nan, nan, nan]]) Notice that there are a lot of NaNs. If you use nearest as the method, you'll always get a solution, but of course linear interpolation needs two things to interpolate between, so the 'edges' of the hypercube are not valid (and 7-D space has a lot of edge!).

My solution has been to stochastically perturb the x and y coordinates of each input point by a random factor between 1e-6 * grid_cell_size. I choose 1e-6 as a rule of thumb of several orders of magnitude greater than the minimum delta difference in a 32 bit float, yet small enough that the error introduced by it is still shadowed by the error introduced by the interpolation scheme. I'm still open to other ideas, but this way I can use the stock interpolation functions provided by scipy by introducing a very small numerical error.

Below is slightly changed example of scipy.interpolate.griddata (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.14.0/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.griddata.html#scipy.interpolate.griddata) usage: import numpy as np from scipy.interpolate import griddata import matplotlib.pyplot as plt k = 300 m, n = 10, 20 x = np.random.random((k,)) * m y = np.random.random((k,)) * n data = np.random.random((k,)) grid_x, grid_y = np.mgrid[0:m+1, 0:n+1] grid_z0 = griddata((x, y), data, (grid_x, grid_y), method='nearest') grid_z1 = griddata((x, y), data, (grid_x, grid_y), method='linear') grid_z2 = griddata((x, y), data, (grid_x, grid_y), method='cubic') plt.subplot(131) plt.imshow(grid_z0.T) plt.title('Nearest') plt.subplot(132) plt.imshow(grid_z1.T) plt.title('Linear') plt.subplot(133) plt.imshow(grid_z2.T) plt.title('Cubic') plt.gcf().set_size_inches(6, 6) plt.show()

SciPy (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SciPy) 0.9 (at the moment, a first beta is out) has a new griddata (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.griddata.html) function that can handle N-dimensional data.

It looks like you want scipy.interpolate.griddata (https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.griddata.html). Here's the example from the documentation: Suppose we want to interpolate the 2-D function >>> def func(x, y): ... return x*(1-x)*np.cos(4*np.pi*x) * np.sin(4*np.pi*y**2)**2 on a grid in [0, 1]x[0, 1] >>> grid_x, grid_y = np.mgrid[0:1:100j, 0:1:200j] but we only know its values at 1000 data points: >>> points = np.random.rand(1000, 2) >>> values = func(points[:,0], points[:,1]) This can be done with griddata – below we try out all of the interpolation methods: >>> from scipy.interpolate import griddata >>> grid_z0 = griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='nearest') >>> grid_z1 = griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='linear') >>> grid_z2 = griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='cubic') One can see that the exact result is reproduced by all of the methods to some degree, but for this smooth function the piecewise cubic interpolant gives the best results: >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt >>> plt.subplot(221) >>> plt.imshow(func(grid_x, grid_y).T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.plot(points[:,0], points[:,1], 'k.', ms=1) >>> plt.title('Original') >>> plt.subplot(222) >>> plt.imshow(grid_z0.T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.title('Nearest') >>> plt.subplot(223) >>> plt.imshow(grid_z1.T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.title('Linear') >>> plt.subplot(224) >>> plt.imshow(grid_z2.T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.title('Cubic') >>> plt.gcf().set_size_inches(6, 6) >>> plt.show() (https://i.stack.imgur.com/PQYnT.png) (source: scipy.org (https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/_images/scipy-interpolate-griddata-1.png))

I think the problem is that the data you're giving it is not smooth enough to interpolate with the default parameters. Here's one approach, using mgrid instead of meshgrid: import numpy as np import pandas as pd from scipy.interpolate import Rbf # fname is your data, but as a CSV file. data = pd.read_csv(fname).values x, y = data.T x_min, x_max = np.amin(x), np.amax(x) y_min, y_max = np.amin(y), np.amax(y) # Make a grid with spacing 0.002. grid_x, grid_y = np.mgrid[x_min:x_max:0.002, y_min:y_max:0.002] # Make up a Z. z = np.hamming(x.size) # Make an n-dimensional interpolator. rbfi = Rbf(x, y, z, smooth=2) # Predict on the regular grid. di = rbfi(grid_x, grid_y) Then you can look at the result: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.imshow(di) I get: (https://i.stack.imgur.com/fGBBX.png) I wrote a Jupyter Notebook (https://github.com/agile-geoscience/xlines/blob/master/notebooks/11_Gridding_map_data.ipynb) on this topic recently, check it out for a few other interpolation methods, like kriging and spline fitting.

If you look at the source code for griddata (https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/4b6f71ab37bda20687ff493669a53cb15fb0b35f/scipy/interpolate/ndgriddata.py#L88) (scroll down past the docstring to see the actual code), you'll see that it is a wrapper for several other interpolation functions, most of which work the way you want. In your case, with 2-d data and cubic interpolation, griddata does this: ip = CloughTocher2DInterpolator(points, values, fill_value=fill_value, rescale=rescale) return ip(xi) So instead of using griddata, you could use CloughTocher2DInterpolator. Specifically, using the names from your script, you would create the interpolator with ip = itp.CloughTocher2DInterpolator(X, Y, fill_value=np.nan, rescale=False) The object ip doesn't have a predict method
column2: you just call it with the points at which you want to evaluate the interpolator. In your case, your would write Y_new = ip(X_new)

column1: Received a tip from an external source that work, so posting the answer in case it helps anyone in the future. SciPy has an Rbf interpolation method (radial basis function) which allows better than linear interpolation at arbitrary dimensions. Taking a variable data with rows of (x1,x2,x3...,xn,v) values, the follow code modification to the original post allows for interpolation: rbfi = Rbf(*data.T) mesh = np.meshgrid(*[i['grid2'] for i in self.cambParams], indexing='ij') chi2 = rbfi(*mesh) The documentation here is useful (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.Rbf.html#scipy.interpolate.Rbf), and there is a simple and easy to follow example here (http://geoexamples.blogspot.com.au/2012/03/creating-grid-from-scattered-data-using.html), which will make more sense than the code snippet above.

Running the example in the griddata doc: In [47]: def func(x, y): return x*(1-x)*np.cos(4*np.pi*x) * np.sin(4*np.pi*y**2)**2 ....: In [48]: points = np.random.rand(1000, 2) In [49]: values = func(points[:,0], points[:,1]) In [50]: grid_x, grid_y = np.mgrid[0:1:100j, 0:1:200j] So we have 1000 scattered points, and will interpolate at 20,000. In [52]: timeit interpolate.griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='nearest') 10 loops, best of 3: 83.6 ms per loop In [53]: timeit interpolate.griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='linear') 1 loops, best of 3: 24.6 ms per loop In [54]: timeit interpolate.griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='cubic') 10 loops, best of 3: 42.7 ms per loop and for the 2 stage interpolators: In [55]: %%timeit rbfi = interpolate.Rbf(points[:,0],points[:,1],values) dl = rbfi(grid_x.ravel(),grid_y.ravel()) ....: 1 loops, best of 3: 3.89 s per loop In [56]: %%timeit ndi=interpolate.NearestNDInterpolator(points, values) dl=ndi(grid_x.ravel(),grid_y.ravel()) ....: 10 loops, best of 3: 82.6 ms per loop In [57]: %%timeit ldi=interpolate.LinearNDInterpolator(points, values) dl=ldi(grid_x.ravel(),grid_y.ravel()) .... 10 loops, best of 3: 25.1 ms per loop griddata is actually a 1 step cover call for these last two versions. griddata describes its methods as: nearest return the value at the data point closest to the point of interpolation. See NearestNDInterpolator for more details. Uses scipy.spatial.cKDTree linear tesselate the input point set to n-dimensional simplices, and interpolate linearly on each simplex. LinearNDInterpolator details are: The interpolant is constructed by triangulating the input data with Qhull [R37], and on each triangle performing linear barycentric interpolation. cubic (2-D) return the value determined from a piecewise cubic, continuously differentiable (C1), and approximately curvature-minimizing polynomial surface. See CloughTocher2DInterpolator for more details. Further tests on the 2 stage versions shows that setting up the nearest cKTtree is very fast
column2: most of the time is spent in the 2nd interpolation state. On the other hand, setting up the triangulated surface takes longer than the linear interpolation. I don't know enough of the Rbf method to say why that is so much slower. The underlying methods are so different that intuitions developed with simple manual methods of interpolation don't mean much. Your example starts with fewer scattered points, and interpolates on a much finer grid.

column1: The basic why is that griddata passes both points and xi through a points = _ndim_coords_from_arrays(points) function whose documentation reads: Convert a tuple of coordinate arrays to a (..., ndim)-shaped array. and key action on tuples is: p = np.broadcast_arrays(*points) anything else, including a list, is just converted to an array: points = np.asanyarray(points) The actual interpolation expects arrays with the '3d' dimension last. So your list of 3 (200,200,200) arrays becomes an array of (3,200,200,200) shape. But your points array is (50,3). The number of dimensions in xi does not match x message results from 200 not matching 3. The griddata documentation is clear about points, less so for xi. But its example uses (x, Y) using arrays from mgrid. So this would work: X, Y, Z = np.meshgrid(*([np.linspace(-1,1,200)] * 3)) interp_vals = scipy.interpolate.griddata(points, values, (X,Y,Z), 'linear') Another way of generating the required array from your meshgrid list is to make it an array, and roll the 1st dimension grid_vals = np.rollaxis(np.array(grid_vals),0,4) Another way of generating a mesh is np.ix_, which returns an open mesh in the form of tuple. An open mesh like this does need the broadcasting. A single point would be interpolated with either: interpolate.griddata(points,values,[[[[0,0,0]]]],'linear') interpolate.griddata(points,values,([0],[0],[0]),'linear') See the reaction to John's 4123 pull request has more discussion about the whys.

Challenges in using scipy.interpolate.griddata for n-dimensional grid interpolation

I think the problem is that you need to make sure you're consistent about the number of dimensions, and the 'domains' of those dimensions. You won't get good results interpolating into places you have not sampled. I think the errors you're getting are related to trying to compute things in these places. Here's how to make something like the example in the scipy.interpolate.griddata docs work for a 7-dimensional example. I'm using a much simpler function which just sums the 'features' in the points data: import numpy as np def func(data): return np.sum(data, axis=1) grid = np.mgrid[0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j, 0:1:5j] points = np.random.rand(100, 7) values = func(points) Notice that the grid covers the entire range of the coordinates points. That is, since each column in points has values in the range 0 to 1, I should make sure I'm making a grid over those same coordinates. from scipy.interpolate import griddata grid_z = griddata(points, values, tuple(grid), method='linear') Now I have this: >>> grid_z[2, 2, 2, 2, 2, :, :] array([[ nan, nan, nan, nan, nan], [ nan, 3. , 3.25, 3.5 , nan], [ nan, 3.25, 3.5 , 3.75, nan], [ nan, 3.5 , 3.75, 4. , nan], [ nan, nan, nan, nan, nan]]) Notice that there are a lot of NaNs. If you use nearest as the method, you'll always get a solution, but of course linear interpolation needs two things to interpolate between, so the 'edges' of the hypercube are not valid (and 7-D space has a lot of edge!).

My solution has been to stochastically perturb the x and y coordinates of each input point by a random factor between 1e-6 * grid_cell_size. I choose 1e-6 as a rule of thumb of several orders of magnitude greater than the minimum delta difference in a 32 bit float, yet small enough that the error introduced by it is still shadowed by the error introduced by the interpolation scheme. I'm still open to other ideas, but this way I can use the stock interpolation functions provided by scipy by introducing a very small numerical error.

Below is slightly changed example of scipy.interpolate.griddata (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.14.0/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.griddata.html#scipy.interpolate.griddata) usage: import numpy as np from scipy.interpolate import griddata import matplotlib.pyplot as plt k = 300 m, n = 10, 20 x = np.random.random((k,)) * m y = np.random.random((k,)) * n data = np.random.random((k,)) grid_x, grid_y = np.mgrid[0:m+1, 0:n+1] grid_z0 = griddata((x, y), data, (grid_x, grid_y), method='nearest') grid_z1 = griddata((x, y), data, (grid_x, grid_y), method='linear') grid_z2 = griddata((x, y), data, (grid_x, grid_y), method='cubic') plt.subplot(131) plt.imshow(grid_z0.T) plt.title('Nearest') plt.subplot(132) plt.imshow(grid_z1.T) plt.title('Linear') plt.subplot(133) plt.imshow(grid_z2.T) plt.title('Cubic') plt.gcf().set_size_inches(6, 6) plt.show()

SciPy (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SciPy) 0.9 (at the moment, a first beta is out) has a new griddata (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.griddata.html) function that can handle N-dimensional data.

It looks like you want scipy.interpolate.griddata (https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.griddata.html). Here's the example from the documentation: Suppose we want to interpolate the 2-D function >>> def func(x, y): ... return x*(1-x)*np.cos(4*np.pi*x) * np.sin(4*np.pi*y**2)**2 on a grid in [0, 1]x[0, 1] >>> grid_x, grid_y = np.mgrid[0:1:100j, 0:1:200j] but we only know its values at 1000 data points: >>> points = np.random.rand(1000, 2) >>> values = func(points[:,0], points[:,1]) This can be done with griddata – below we try out all of the interpolation methods: >>> from scipy.interpolate import griddata >>> grid_z0 = griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='nearest') >>> grid_z1 = griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='linear') >>> grid_z2 = griddata(points, values, (grid_x, grid_y), method='cubic') One can see that the exact result is reproduced by all of the methods to some degree, but for this smooth function the piecewise cubic interpolant gives the best results: >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt >>> plt.subplot(221) >>> plt.imshow(func(grid_x, grid_y).T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.plot(points[:,0], points[:,1], 'k.', ms=1) >>> plt.title('Original') >>> plt.subplot(222) >>> plt.imshow(grid_z0.T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.title('Nearest') >>> plt.subplot(223) >>> plt.imshow(grid_z1.T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.title('Linear') >>> plt.subplot(224) >>> plt.imshow(grid_z2.T, extent=(0,1,0,1), origin='lower') >>> plt.title('Cubic') >>> plt.gcf().set_size_inches(6, 6) >>> plt.show() (https://i.stack.imgur.com/PQYnT.png) (source: scipy.org (https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/_images/scipy-interpolate-griddata-1.png))

Here is a modified version of the code to fix the issue of inconsistent dimensions:
# Fix the issue of inconsistent dimensions
Note that we've replaced `tuple(grid)` with `(grid_x, grid_y)` to ensure that the dimensions are consistent.
Alternatively, you can also use `np.ix_` to generate the mesh:
# Use np.ix_ to generate the mesh
Both of these approaches should resolve the issue of inconsistent dimensions and allow you to perform the interpolation correctly.
Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns!
Also, note that the `griddata` function is designed to work with 2D grids, so if you need to interpolate in higher dimensions, you may need to use a different approach.

Additionally, if you're dealing with large datasets, you may want to consider using a more efficient interpolation algorithm, such as the `scipy.interpolate.Rbf` class, which uses radial basis functions to perform interpolation.

Bootstrap 3 modal not showing,"

The #login modal doesn't appear because it's inside the #register modal.
You should add another div close tag before the #login modal declaration.
The reason why the modal is not visible is that its parent, the #register modal, is hidden.

You have not included bootstrap-dialog.js. I tried running your code into jsfiddle and it gave me ReferenceError: BootstrapDialog is not defined you can find bootstrap-dialog-js on nakupanda's github account : https://github.com/nakupanda/bootstrap3-dialog/tree/master/src/js (https://github.com/nakupanda/bootstrap3-dialog/tree/master/src/js)

Ok after some research I solved my problem, I hope others will benefit from it. This post actually solved it: here (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17575687/bootstrap-3-0-modal) Apparently the syntax for the modal in Bootstrap 3 is different and among other things it has to include these lines: <div class=""modal-dialog""> <div class=""modal-content""> So I took the example under the link, tweaked it for my purposes and it worked. Problem solved.

I got a reply from from Dante (https://github.com/nakupanda) creator of this plugin I share this bellow which is working fine with extra parameter . https://github.com/nakupanda/bootstrap3-dialog/issues/329 (https://github.com/nakupanda/bootstrap3-dialog/issues/329)

I had the same issue when upgrading to Bootstrap 3. Check the classes and structure in the HTML for your modal. It should look like this: <div class=""modal fade""> <div class=""modal-dialog""> <div class=""modal-content""> <div class=""modal-header""> <button type=""button"" class=""close"" data-dismiss=""modal"" aria-hidden=""true"">&times
column3: Docs: http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#modals (http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#modals)

column1: You do have a BootstrapDialog.defaultOptions around line 231 in the master repo (https://github.com/nakupanda/bootstrap3-dialog/blob/master/dist/js/bootstrap-dialog.js#L231). Use that to modify the defaults to whatever you need : $.extend( BootstrapDialog.defaultOptions, { closable: true, closeByBackdrop: true, autodestroy: false } )
column2: and take benefit of the new settings in all dialogs : var myDialog = new BootstrapDialog({ title: 'Example', message: 'Sample text' }).open() demo -> http://jsfiddle.net/ffj6r1b6/ (http://jsfiddle.net/ffj6r1b6/) (try change closeByBackdrop to false and re-run)

column1: Please provide your best answer below:
The solution to your problem is quite simple.
Firstly, make sure you've included bootstrap-dialog.js file in your html file. You can download it from nakupanda's github page or use cdn.
Secondly, check the syntax of your modal. As mentioned earlier, the syntax for modal in Bootstrap 3 is different.
Lastly, check if there are any errors in your console. If there are any errors related to bootstrap-dialog, then it might be because of a conflict between different versions of jQuery.

,Using Python Pandas: What is the method to tally occurrences of a specific value in one column, contingent on the criteria of another column?","
Using Python Pandas: What is the method to tally occurrences of a specific value in one column, contingent on the criteria of another column?

Here is an example of a simple 'countif' recipe you could try: import pandas as pd def countif(rng, criteria): return rng.eq(criteria).sum() Example use df = pd.DataFrame({'column1': [4,4,3,2,4,1], 'column2': [1,2,3,4,5,6]}) countif(df['column1'], 1)
You can create boolean mask and then count Trues by sum, Trues are processes like 1s: (df['College/Univ'] == 'Texas A&M').sum()

This post explains very well you you can combine an external JSON file with an html file: How to read an external local JSON file in Javascript (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19706046/how-to-read-an-external-local-json-file-in-javascript) However! What you are having is not an json file. What i would suggest is getting your JSON data, store it within its own file and use the .json extension and then follow the example shown in the post
You can embed the JSON in the HTML document, either by hard-coding it or using server-side programming to generate the HTML.

One option is to write a JavaScript file instead of plain JSON, then just add a script-tag to your HTML-page and you have access to your JSON data. Javascript to be written, e.g. mydata.js: var myJSON = {.....}
column2: In HTML you just include <script src=""mydata.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script> Now you can access myJSON from any script in your HTML-page. Hope that helps.

column1: I see that you didn't include the jquery (/questions/tagged/jquery) tag, so I'll provide a couple of vanilla javascript solutions: If the file is located at an accesible directory, you can pull the data like this: Define your JSON object as follows: Original: [{ ""name"" : ""John"", ""date"" : ""01-27-2014"" }] Modified into javascript: var data = '[{ ""name"" : ""John"", ""date"" : ""01-27-2014"" }]'
column2: And save it to a plain text document named mydata.json.js, for example (the double extension has nothing to do with the content itself). So it becomes a valid javascript file and you can load it on your html like this: <script src=""mydata.json.js""></script> And you can use your data var on your HTML normally. Or use this if you don't have the document locally or the above approach is too makeshifty for you. column1: Two options you have: Include the JSON within your javascript code itself. Request the file via an AJAX call.

The file you call values.json is not JSON, but a script in the JavaScript language. Such a script you can indeed include and run via the script tag. If however you want to have JSON format for your data, and you want to have it loaded from a file into your other JavaScript code, then proceed like this: Put JSON in your file (no variable names, no assignments, no trailing semi-colon, just JSON) -- it can only be one data structure, so let's use an array: [{""Laura"" : 45, ""Pekka"" : 89, ""Jussi"" : 35, ""Kalle"" : 25}, {""Laura"" : 75, ""Pekka"" : 59, ""Jussi"" : 85, ""Kalle"" : 95}, {""Laura"" : 55, ""Pekka"" : 15, ""Jussi"" : 45, ""Kalle"" : 67}] Remove the script src= tag. Mark the DOMContentLoaded callback function as asynchronous: document.addEventListener(""DOMContentLoaded"", async function(event) { // ^^^^^ Add code within that callback to load and parse the JSON into a variable arr: var response = await fetch(""values.json"")

column1:
If you don't want to request the JSON file from the client as an independent HTTP request you can do one of the following: Full server side rendering: Use a template technology like moustache (http://mustache.github.io/) or handlebars (http://handlebarsjs.com/), and try to render that data inline with the response. For example if you your JSON file returns a name and an address the index.html could look like:
Name: {{name}}
Address: {{address}}
Then when rendering you could pass a js object with properties name and address to the template and you wouldn't need to ask for the JSON file separately. This example follows moustache guidelines just in case I wasn't explicit enough. Inline object A bit like the previous solution but less elegant, you can add the full JSON response as an object with within a script tag, and then use it however you see fit. Try to append a block to he HEAD of index.html like this: The other possible solution was just described in another answer. I hope this helps.

JSON isn't Javascript. You can't load a JSON file in a script tag. You need to use AJAX to load JSON from the web. The JSON file should be served with an application/json content-type. I suggest you investigate XMLHttpRequest, or, if you want an easier ride, jQuery's AJAX methods.

Your json has an entire web page, starting with the tag. You can't insert this html inside a div. If you are getting this json as a Ajax request, you could do this: $.ajax( { .. , success: function (data) { document.open()

column1: Please provide your best answer below:
To incorporate a JSON file within an HTML document, there are several approaches you can take depending on your specific needs and constraints. Here are some common methods:

You can directly embed the JSON data within the HTML document using a `<script>` tag with the `type` attribute set to `application/json`. This method is straightforward, but it may not be suitable for large datasets.

You can use the `XMLHttpRequest` object or the Fetch API to load the JSON data from an external file. This method allows you to separate the data from the presentation layer and make it more maintainable.

If you're using a server-side language like PHP, Node.js, or Ruby, you can generate the HTML document with the embedded JSON data. This method requires setting up a server environment, but it provides a robust solution for dynamic data generation.
As mentioned in the Stack Overflow answer, you can create a global variable to store the retrieved JSON data. This method assumes that you're working within a single JavaScript file or scope.
// Load JSON data using AJAX or another method

There are various libraries and frameworks available that simplify the process of loading and manipulating JSON data, such as jQuery or React. These tools often provide built-in support for handling JSON data and can streamline your development workflow.
Remember to consider factors like performance, security, and maintainability when choosing the most suitable approach for your project.

Based on the provided context and examples, I recommend using Method 2: Loading JSON via AJAX. This approach separates the data from the presentation layer, making it more maintainable and scalable. Additionally, using the Fetch API or XMLHttpRequest object allows for efficient data retrieval and manipulation. If you're working within a specific framework or library, consider leveraging its built-in features for handling JSON data. Always prioritize security and performance"

How can I check if a regex matches forever?,"

There is no such thing as a regex matching infinitely
column2: thus being stuck in an infinite loop. As an example, the regex .* will stop immediately when there are 0 characters and will run for n iterations on any string of n characters.

column1: A regex is a form of a finite state machine. A string, its input, is also always finite. There is no infinite in regular expressions.

column1: Please provide your best answer below:
You cannot determine if a regex pattern will run indefinitely because it will not. The maximum number of steps that a DFA can take to match or fail is equal to the size of the input plus one.
This can be proven by using the following two points:
*   Every step of a regex pattern corresponds to a transition from one state to another.

*   In order to process each character in the string, we must make at least one transition between states. Therefore, given an input of length `n`, the number of transitions required is at least `n`. Adding one extra transition for the final acceptance or rejection state gives us a total of `n + 1` possible transitions.
Therefore, since every regex pattern can only have `n+1` steps to match or fail a string of length `n`, you cannot have a regex running indefinitely.

However, a regex engine may still hang if it enters an infinite loop due to an error or misimplementation in the regex engine itself, but this is not related to the regex pattern's behavior. For instance, consider a regex pattern like `a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a*a"

JAVA - Implementing calculations through functional interfaces

The basic arithmetic operations are addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. And these are essentially Algebraic Operations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_operation). This means that they are operations on an algebraic structure, and the structure is essentially what you tried to model with your interface. Specifically, the structure that you need for these operations is a Field (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_(mathematics)). There already are libraries that model a Field class (http://jscience.org/api/org/jscience/mathematics/structure/Field.html) and give a glimpse at how complicated this can be if you're trying to do it right. In the purest sense, there is no such thing as ""subtraction"", but only the addition of the inverse element (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_element). Similarly, a division is the multiplication with the multiplicative inverse (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiplicative_inverse), with 0.0 being the odd case where no such element exists. Ouch. The exact semantics of methods like double element_i(int i)
column2: would have to be specified. Sure, it makes sense for complex numbers, but not for all possible implementations. A very simplistic sketch of a possible GeneralNumber interface and one implementation is shown here: class Arithmetic { static <T> GeneralNumber<T> computeSomething( GeneralNumber<T> a, GeneralNumber<T> b) { GeneralNumber<T> c = a.add(b)
column3: // c = a + b GeneralNumber<T> d = c.additiveInverse()
column13: } class GeneralDoubleNumber implements GeneralNumber<Double> { static GeneralDoubleNumber of(double d) { return new GeneralDoubleNumber(d)
column17: } @Override public GeneralNumber<Double> add(GeneralNumber<Double> a) { return of(get() + a.get())
column20: } @Override public GeneralNumber<Double> multiply(GeneralNumber<Double> a) { return of(get() * a.get())
column21: } @Override public GeneralNumber<Double> multiplicativeInverse() { return of(1.0 / get())
column23: } } But note that, in some ways, it would make sense to pull the operations out of the structures that they operate on. And keep in mind that the complexity of all this tends to grow out of hand when you consider the fact that the arithmetic operations may modify the domain. The difference between an Instant and an Instant should not be an Instant, but a Duration...

Java 8 Date equivalent to Joda's DateTimeFormatterBuilder with multiple parser formats?,"

There is no direct facility to do this, but you can use optional sections. Optional sections are enclosed inside squared brackets []. This allows for the whole section of the String to parse to be missing.
This formatter defines 3 grand optional sections for the three main patterns you have. Each of them is inside its own optional section.
,How can I achieve multiple parsing formats for dates in Java 8 similar to Joda's DateTimeFormatterBuilder?,
How can I achieve multiple parsing formats for dates in Java 8 similar to Joda's DateTimeFormatterBuilder?

I've made tests with JodaTime 2.7 and found 2 ways to do it: Use DateTimeFormatterBuilder's optional parsers: // create parser for ""GMT"" DateTimeParser gmtParser = DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""ZZZ"").getParser()
column3: DateTimeFormatter formatter = new DateTimeFormatterBuilder() .appendPattern(""EEE, dd MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss "") // common pattern .appendOptional(gmtParser) // optional parser for GMT .appendOptional(offsetParser) // optional parser for +0200 .toFormatter().withLocale(Locale.ENGLISH).withOffsetParsed()
column4: DateTimeFormatterBuilder can receive an array of parsers that can be used to parse different inputs: // create array with all possible patterns DateTimeParser[] parsers = { DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""EEE, dd MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss Z"").getParser(), DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""EEE, dd MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss ZZZ"").getParser() }

The second solution is better if the patterns are very different from each other. But I also believe it's a matter of opinion and it's up to you to choose.

column1: in Joda Time you can use multiple parser, you can check this SO answer Using Joda Date & Time API to parse multiple formats (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3307330/using-joda-date-time-api-to-parse-multiple-formats)

You would need to write either a separate library, or a DateTimeParser. DateTimeParser is the interface used internally by Joda-Time to parse text. Anyone can implement it and plug it directly into the Joda-Time parsing system using DateTimeFormatterBuilder.

Outside of using Joda's DateTimeParser yourself and essentially parsing the text yourself building up a valid DateTime (which i think would be a lot of work), i don't think there's really much wrong with your approach. I do think that you have too many formats though. I think your set of formats could be reduced to: DateTimeParser[] parsers = { DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""E, d MMM y HH:mm:ss Z"").getParser(), DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""E, d MMM y HH:mm:ss Z '('z')'"").getParser(), DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""E, d MMM y HH:mm:ss z"").getParser(), DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""dd MMM y HH:mm:ss Z"").getParser(), }
column2: Z (Capital-Z) is the RFC 822 numeric timezone and small-z is the acronym for the timezone, like PDT, for example. This is still (on average) 2 exceptions thrown per parse request but if this doesn't need to be high-performance, that's probably not so bad.

column1: DateTimeFormatterBuilder#appendFixedDecimal() (https://www.joda.org/joda-time/apidocs/org/joda/time/format/DateTimeFormatterBuilder.html#appendFixedDecimal-org.joda.time.DateTimeFieldType-int-) may well do what you need. Alternatively, you could implement the DateTimeParser (https://www.joda.org/joda-time/apidocs/org/joda/time/format/DateTimeParser.html) interface to create whatever parser you want and pass that into the DateTimeFormatterBuilder.

column1: You cannot use a predefined formatter but you can construct your own one (and assign it to a static constant) using following pattern: static final DateTimeFormatter DATE_TIME_OPTIONAL_OFFSET = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern(""uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss[xxx]"")
column2: Attention: If you parse an input containing only date and time but without offset (and without any offset/zone-default) then the result can only be a LocalDateTime, not a global timestamp. Please also note the different behaviour of method withZone(...). Joda-Time When parsing, this zone will be set on the parsed datetime. A null zone means of no-override. If both an override chronology and an override zone are set, the override zone will take precedence over the zone in the chronology. Java-8 (JSR-310) When parsing, there are two distinct cases to consider. If a zone has been parsed directly from the text, perhaps because DateTimeFormatterBuilder.appendZoneId() was used, then this override Zone has no effect. If no zone has been parsed, then this override zone will be included in the result of the parse where it can be used to build instants and date-times. Side remark: The Joda-Time-method withOffsetParsed() is closer to Java-8-behaviour. Update: I have now done my own tests. See the sometimes surprising results. Maybe a newer Java-version 8u40 has meanwhile corrected some of the problems shown (at least the behaviour of withZone() is probably corrected - see JDK-issue 8033662 (https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8033662), but for 8u31 the backport fix appears to be missing?!). You should also note that your ""timezone"" labelled ""EST"" was replaced by ""America/New_York"" in my tests because ""EST"" is not a recognized timezone id (it is rather a localized timezone name abbreviation in US). Update - final solution After extra testing this code seems to work in Java 8u31 (assuming UTC as default in case of missing offset in input): static final DateTimeFormatter DATE_TIME_OPTIONAL_OFFSET = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern(""uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss[xxx]"")

column1: I'm using Joda-Time 2.9.7 and JDK 1.7.0_79. You can use DateTimeFormatterBuilder.append method (http://www.joda.org/joda-time/apidocs/org/joda/time/format/DateTimeFormatterBuilder.html#append-org.joda.time.format.DateTimePrinter-org.joda.time.format.DateTimeParser:A-): it receives a printer (with a pattern used to print date/times) and an array of parsers with all possible input patterns: import org.joda.time.DateTime
column7: // array of parsers, with all possible input patterns DateTimeParser[] parsers = { // parser for MM/dd/yyyy format monthDayYear.getParser(), // parser for yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss format DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss"").getParser() }
column8: DateTimeFormatter parser = new DateTimeFormatterBuilder() // use the monthDayYear formatter for output (monthDayYear.getPrinter()) and parsers array for input (parsers) .append(monthDayYear.getPrinter(), parsers) // create formatter (using UTC to avoid DST problems) .toFormatter().withZone(DateTimeZone.UTC)
column9: // test with MM/dd/yyyy DateTime datetime1 = parser.parseDateTime(""06/14/2017"")
column13: // 06/14/2017 I've used DateTimeZone.UTC to avoid problems with Daylight Saving Time. For example, in my default timezone (America/Sao_Paulo), last year (2016), DST started at October 16th: at midnight, the clocks move 1 hour ahead (so, tecnically, midnight doesn't exist at this day, because time changes from 23:59:59 to 01:00:00). The problem is, when parsing MM/dd/yyyy format, there's no fields for hour, minute or second, and the parser sets 0 as a default value for all these fields (so the hour becomes midnight). But if I try to parse in a date where DST starts (like 10/16/2016) and don't use the UTC as above, the code throws an exception because midnight doesn't exist in that day (due to DST hour shift). Using UTC avoids this error, as DateTimeZone.UTC has no DST effects. With this, the code works independent of your system's default timezone. The output is: 06/14/2017 06/14/2017 PS: As you care only about the date part (day/month/year), you could also use the org.joda.time.LocalDate class. To use it, just change the last part of the code (you can use the same parser): // test with MM/dd/yyyy LocalDate dt1 = parser.parseLocalDate(""06/14/2017"")
column17: // 06/14/2017 The output is the same: 06/14/2017 06/14/2017 Using a LocalDate is another way to avoid problems with Daylight Saving Time (as explained above). In this case, you don't need to set UTC, because LocalDate has no timezone information.

column1: The list of valid formats for the constructor you are using are detailed in the javadoc of ISODateTimeFormat (http://joda-time.sourceforge.net/apidocs/org/joda/time/format/ISODateTimeFormat.html#dateTimeParser%28%29), which does not include ""mm/dd/yyyy"": datetime = time | date-opt-time time = 'T' time-element [offset] date-opt-time = date-element ['T' [time-element] [offset]] date-element = std-date-element | ord-date-element | week-date-element std-date-element = yyyy ['-' MM ['-' dd]] ord-date-element = yyyy ['-' DDD] week-date-element = xxxx '-W' ww ['-' e] time-element = HH [minute-element] | [fraction] minute-element = ':' mm [second-element] | [fraction] second-element = ':' ss [fraction] fraction = ('.' | ',') digit+ offset = 'Z' | (('+' | '-') HH [':' mm [':' ss [('.' | ',') SSS]]]) You can parse a different format with a DateTimeFormatter (http://joda-time.sourceforge.net/api-release/org/joda/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html) (note MM in upper case for month): DateTimeFormatter fmt = DateTimeFormat.forPattern(""MM/dd/yyyy"")

,JavaScript: How to alter an object using a reference?,
JavaScript: How to alter an object using a reference?

Objects are passed as reference in JavaScript, but the reference itself is a value. In other words, you can only change the members of the input object, but not its reference. What happens in the line obj = new Object()
column2: is that the local copy of the reference to ""obj"" is modified, but this local copy is discarded when the function returns.

column1: In your function modify(o) you are assigning the variable o a new object reference, leaving the original obj untouched. If you want to modify the original object, access it directly: var obj = { a: ""hello"" }
column2: function modify(o) { o.a = ""hello world"" // this modifies the object passed to the function } modify(obj)

column1: Is there any way to achieve this? Not directly. All you can do is pass an object and have the function modify a property on it, as in your first example. JavaScript does not have pass-by-reference, just pass-by-value. (The value may be an object reference, of course, but it's still a value.) There's no way in JavaScript to directly modify the variable/property you're passing into the function, because what the function receives is a copy of the value of that variable/property, not a reference to that variable/property. Just to be clear about something: In your first code block, you said you were ""sending the object to the function."" That's incorrect. You send a reference to the object to the function. This is the key thing to understand: Variables, properties, and function arguments (collectively, ""variables"") contain values, and those values are copied when you use assignment or when you pass them into functions. The value that refers to an object is called an object reference, because the value isn't the object, it's a reference to (pointer to) the object elsewhere in memory. The reference is copied when you pass it into a function, the object is not. Don't confuse the ""reference"" in ""object reference"" with the ""reference"" in ""pass-by-reference,"" they're completely different things. (In pass-by-reference, the reference is to the variable, not an object. JavaScript doesn't have pass-by-reference.)
In JavaScript, things are passed around by value. In your initial code: var ref = originalObj
column2: The value of originalObj has been copied to ref. That value is a reference to an object, so both variables have independent copies of that reference, but they both reference the same underlying object. Changes in the object are reflected in both variables. In this: var fooRef = originalObj.foo
column3: Again, the value of originalObj.foo is being copied, but this time that value is just a number, 1. At this point, the variable and the property have independent copies of that value, but it's just a number, not a reference to an object. Changes in either of these are not reflect in the other. how can I circumvent it? By using your first block of code - you need a reference to the object containing the property you wish to update - you're unable to update a variable or property directly by keeping a reference/pointer to it.

column1: pointing to some properties with local variables You cannot. JavaScript doesn't have pointers. All variables hold values. When I change the array value, the property changes as well (as expected). Not really. You mutate the array object. The property hasn't changed, it still contains the reference to the array. Why don't strings or numbers change in their corresponding object properties? Strings and numbers are primitive values - you can't mutate them. You are reassigning the variable with a new value. You're not reassigning the property, thereby not changing it. The same happens for arrays and other object when you reassign the variable - ref3 = []
column2: doesn't change the property. Is it possible to change the properties via a reference variable? No. You could use a with statement (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/with), but this is despised. Better be explicit about object properties.

column1: It's not possible. What confuses you is that in js runtime you don't have a way to manage the actual reference values, but only can assign some reference value to a variable. That's it - you can ""attach"" another reference to a given variable name, but you cannot modify the reference value. To clear what I said above: the memory for object is allocated on its initialization var o = {}
column2: after that the reference to an unnamed object (objects don't have names, variables do) is assigned to a o variable. After that you cannot re-allocate another object to the same place in memory.

column1: JavaScript acts this pass by reference differently (somewhat). Basically everything is passed by value in JavaScript. If you pass an object to a function and change some property in you and you have access to those changed values outside that function, that makes us guess that it's passed by reference, but actually for objects the value of the variable is a reference. You can't actually achieve this using JavaScript but there's simple workarounds you can follow. If you know that every object in JavaScript is a flavor of Dictionary of Key Value pair, and all variables can be accessed by indexers. In your case, as i said the value of the variable is a reference and its pointless to change the value where it wouldn't persist. And you also know that your current context (this) is the global so you may access your variable through indexer and change the value by name. The only difference is, you are passing the name of the function as string. var carToy, trainToy

column10: That's the best you can do in my opinion.

column1: Objects are Passed by Reference In JavaScript (http://www.w3schools.com/js/js_function_parameters.asp) object references are values. Because of this, objects will behave like they are passed by reference: If a function changes an object property, it changes the original value. Changes to object properties are visible (reflected) outside the function. if you assign an object to property of another object it is still assigned by reference. while you change the new object value it reflect in base. eg: var myObj = { a: 1 } var testObj = { ref: myObj } console.log(myObj.a)

column1: Is there any way to achieve this? Not directly. All you can do is pass an object and have the function modify a property on it, as in your first example. JavaScript does not have pass-by-reference, just pass-by-value. (The value may be an object reference, of course, but it's still a value.) There's no way in JavaScript to directly modify the variable/property you're passing into the function, because what the function receives is a copy of the value of that variable/property, not a reference to that variable/property. Just to be clear about something: In your first code block, you said you were ""sending the object to the function."" That's incorrect. You send a reference to the object to the function. This is the key thing to understand: Variables, properties, and function arguments (collectively, ""variables"") contain values, and those values are copied when you use assignment or when you pass them into functions. The value that refers to an object is called an object reference, because the value isn't the object, it's a reference to (pointer to) the object elsewhere in memory. The reference is copied when you pass it into a function, the object is not. Don't confuse the ""reference"" in ""object reference"" with the ""reference"" in ""pass-by-reference,"" they're completely different things. (In pass-by-reference, the reference is to the variable, not an object. JavaScript doesn't have pass-by-reference.)
In JavaScript, things are passed around by value. In your initial code: var ref = originalObj
column2: The value of originalObj has been copied to ref. ## Step 2: Identify potential issues with applying multiple CSS classes

When applying multiple CSS classes to an HTML element, there could be conflicts between the styles defined by these classes. This might cause unexpected behavior or render the click function ineffective.
## Step 3: Consider the impact of CSS class order on style application

In CSS, the order in which classes are applied can affect which styles take precedence. If a later-applied class overrides styles from an earlier-applied class, this could lead to inconsistent styling that interferes with the functionality of the click event handler.
## Step 4: Analyze how CSS specificity affects style application

CSS specificity determines the priority of styles when there are conflicts. Classes have lower specificity than IDs and inline styles, so if a class is overridden by another class or an ID, it may not have any effect on the element's appearance or behavior.
## Step 5: Determine why the click function might be ineffective

Given the potential for CSS class conflicts and the impact of specificity, it's possible that the click function is being overridden or affected by the styles applied through one or both of the classes. This could prevent the expected behavior from occurring.
## Step 6: Suggest a solution to resolve the issue

To resolve this issue, inspect the HTML element and its applied CSS classes to identify any potential conflicts. Then, adjust the class names, their order, or use more specific selectors to ensure that the desired styles are applied without interfering with each other or the click event handler.

To be clear, we understand what's causing this. We recently made ready

after the load event if the load event fires quickly enough. The side
effect you're seeing in this issue is that you're binding a load event
handler after the load event has already fired.

Why isn't $(window).on('load') functioning properly when used within jQuery(document).ready()?
Why are you using $(window).load()? I'm asking if there's a specific reason or not. The standard jQuery way uses DOMReady via: $(document).ready() Or: $(function(){ })

Check this discussion window.onload vs $(document).ready() (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3698200/window-onload-vs-document-ready) The order of events depends on the browser you are using. There is a subtle difference. Read through the article and make necessary changes if possible to ""onload"" rather than ""ready"".

You are making a confusion between document and window. $(document).ready(function() { // document is now ready $(document).on('load', function() { // doesn't work }) $(window).on('load', function() { // window is now fully loaded })

window.onload may not get executed for a number of reasons. Some resource on the page isn't loaded (images), since window.onload only fires after all resources have loaded. Something is overwriting window.onload You have a javascript error somewhere else My suggestion to you is that since you're using jQuery, use either: $(document).ready(function(){ /* initialize stuff */})
column2: or if you actually need onload $(window).load(function(){ /* initialize stuff */})
column3: For your example I would recommend using the $(document).ready(...) method as it looks to me your script will work as soon as the dom is ready, which is when the ready event fires.

column1: The document.ready event is fired once the page has finished loading. Inside this second ready handler you're then trying to assign the loaded function to window.onload, which would have already fired by this point.

If you want to wait untill the whole page and all its resources have been completely loaded, you need to use $(window).load() (http://api.jquery.com/load-event/). ## Step 1: Understand the context of the problem
The problem is about understanding why $(window).on('load') is not functioning properly when used within jQuery(document).ready(). We also have some discussions from other sources.
We want to clarify what $(window).on('load') does, how it differs from $(document).ready(), and why they are not interchangeable.
## Step 3: Explain the differences between $(document).ready() and $(window).on('load')

$(document).ready() is a callback function that is invoked when the initial HTML document has been completely loaded and parsed, without waiting for stylesheets, images, etc., while $(window).on('load') waits until all assets such as images, stylesheets, scripts have loaded before firing.

Some users believe that $(document).ready() ensures everything is loaded, but this is not true. Other users think that $(window).on('load') should always be used instead of $(document).ready(), but again this is not correct.
## Step 5: Provide advice based on the context of the problem

Based on the given information, we suggest sticking with the traditional jQuery approach: $(document).ready() unless there's a strong reason to use $(window).on('load'), such as needing to ensure certain heavy-loaded content (like videos, large images, or complex graphics) is fully loaded before executing some JavaScript logic.
There is no single answer to this question, as it seems to be more about clarifying the usage of different event handlers provided by jQuery. However, to summarize the key points:
*   $(document).ready() is triggered when the DOM is ready, whereas $(window).on('load') waits for all assets (including images and scripts) to finish loading.
*   Both methods can be useful depending on the specific requirements of the application.
*   When deciding between these two approaches, consider whether the code inside the handler needs to execute immediately after the DOM is ready or if it requires the entire page to be fully loaded.

How does Garbage Collection work with multiple running processes/threads?,"

A process can have several threads.
Garbage collection works within one process.
On systems that support fork: If you disable the garbage collection in one process and then fork it (= create a copy of the process) then GC should also be disabled in the copy.
If new processes are created which are not a copy then they have their own garbage collection configuration. By defaut their GC should be turned on.
But there are a lot of libraries which have a Process class. I can not tell what they do. If you use os to spawn a new process (not a copy) then it should run with GC turned on.

The configuration of one process's GC has no effect on the configuration of an other's GC. Processes are boundaries to protect code from oneanother. So anything in one process is not able to reach into an other process, easily.

column1: The answer is that this depends on the garbage collection algorithms used. In some cases, you are correct that all threads are stopped during GC. In other cases, you are incorrect in that garbage collection proceeds while normal threads are running. To understand how GC's achieve that, you need a detailed understanding of the theory and terminology of garbage collectors, combined with an understanding of the specific collector. It is simply not amenable to a simple explanation. Oh yes, and it is worth pointing out that many modern collectors don't have a compaction phase per-se. Rather they work by copying live objects to a new ""space"" and zeroing the old ""space"" when they are done. If I am incorrect my question would be answered by a simple explanation of the strategy used to minimise blocking. If you really want to understand how garbage collectors work, I recommend: ""Garbage Collection: Algorithms for Automatic Dynamic Memory Management"" (https://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/com/0471941484) by Richard Jones. ""The Garbage Collection Handbook: The Art of Automatic Memory Management"" (https://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/com/1420082795) by Richard Jones, Antony Hosking and Eliot Moss ... and beware that finding accurate, detailed, public descriptions of the internals of production garbage collectors is not easy. (Though in the case of the Hotspot GC's, you can look at the source code ...) EDIT: in response to the OP's comment ... ""It seems it is as I thought -- there is no getting around the ""stop the world"" part."" It depends. In the case of the Java 6 Concurrent Collector (http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/hotspot/gc/gc_tuning_6.html#cms), there are two pauses during the marking of the roots (including stacks), and then marking / copying of other objects proceeds in parallel. For other kinds of concurrent collector, read or write barriers are used while the collector is running to trap situations where the collector and application threads would otherwise interfere with each other. I don't have my copy of [Jones] here right now, but I also recall that it is possible to make the ""stop the world"" interval negligible ... at the cost of more expensive pointer operations and/or not collecting all garbage.

## Step 1: Understand the context of the problem

The problem is asking about the interaction between garbage collection and concurrently executing processes and threads. This involves understanding how garbage collection works within a single process and across multiple processes.
## Step 2: Identify key points about garbage collection

Key points include: - Garbage collection works within one process. - On systems that support fork, disabling garbage collection in one process disables it in the copied process. - New processes have their own garbage collection configuration, defaulting to being enabled. - Libraries may introduce custom Process classes affecting garbage collection. - Using os to spawn new processes results in garbage collection being enabled. - Processes isolate code from one another, preventing interference.

In Java, garbage collection runs in parallel with threads. A sample code demonstrates creating threads that continue running even after the main method finishes, indicating concurrent execution of garbage collection and threads.
## Step 4: Analyze the impact of garbage collection algorithms

Different garbage collection algorithms handle concurrent execution differently. Some stop all threads during garbage collection, while others proceed with garbage collection while allowing normal threads to run. Understanding these strategies requires knowledge of garbage collector theory and terminology.
## Step 5: Provide recommendations for further study

To fully comprehend the intricacies of garbage collection and its interactions with concurrent processes and threads, studying resources such as ""Garbage Collection: Algorithms for Automatic Dynamic Memory Management"" and ""The Garbage Collection Handbook"" is recommended.
The final answer is: $\boxed{There is no straightforward answer as it heavily depends on the specifics of the garbage collection algorithm used.}$

# First, we check if the input is a list. If not, raise an error.
raise ValueError(""Input must be a list."")
# Then, we check if all elements in the list are numbers. If not, raise an error.
if not all(isinstance(temp, (int, float)) for temp in temperature_list):
raise ValueError(""All elements in the list must be numbers."")
# Next, we calculate the sum of all temperatures in the list.
# After that, we count the number of temperatures in the list.
# Finally, we calculate and return the mean temperature by dividing the sum by the count.

This code defines a function `compute_mean_temperature` that takes a list of temperatures as input, checks for valid input types, calculates the sum and count of temperatures, and returns the mean temperature by dividing the sum by the count. It also includes example usage with a sample list of temperatures. The function raises errors if the input is not a list or contains non-numeric values. The output is formatted as a string with the units ""degrees."" to match the context's requirements.
The provided solution adheres to professional guidelines, using clear variable names, descriptive comments, and proper error handling. It also follows the PEP 8 style guide for Python code.

Note that this function assumes that the input list can contain both Celsius and Fahrenheit temperatures. node-static cannot serve a folder above current folder,"

Be aware that using relative paths will resolve those paths relative to the current working directory of the node.js process, that is, the directory you were in when you ran node server.js. So as coded, your could looks OK to me as long as you are in the core directory when you launch node. Are you sure you always launch node from the core directory?

If you want to be independent of the cwd (more robust IMHO), use __dirname to get the absolute directory path of the current file and then tack on your relative paths to that: __dirname + '/../../public'.

Beyond that, consider fs.realpath to resolve those. I can't say whether node-static in particular has special code to prevent this, but most other modules I've seen such as connect's static middleware will happily serve any arbitrary directory without special restrictions.

Please provide your best answer below:

The reason why `node-static` cannot access and serve directories located above its current directory is because it uses a combination of `__filename` and `path.resolve()` to calculate the root directory of the application. The root directory is used as the base for all served files. This means that if you try to serve a directory above the current working directory, it will not work because `path.resolve()` does not follow symbolic links by default.
Here is an example of how you can modify `node-static` to allow serving directories above the current working directory:

In the modified version, we use `fs.realpathSync()` to get the real path of the current directory, which follows symbolic links. We then use this real path as the root directory of the application. This allows us to serve directories above the current working directory.
You should also note that this modification may have security implications if you're serving untrusted content. You should ensure that you're properly validating user input before serving it.

This solution assumes you want to serve the index.html file inside each directory. If you don't need this feature, you can simply remove the logic related to the index.html file. Also, keep in mind that this solution serves files based on their physical location on disk, so if your project structure changes over time (e.g., due to code reorganization or external library updates), the served files might point to different locations than expected. Consider using a more flexible approach like serving files based on their virtual paths instead."

If this is not what you were looking for please clarify the problem and I will be happy to help you further.
This code snippet retrieves all objects that contain `childObj` in their `children` field.

Note that this will return all parents of `childObj`, not just its immediate parent. If you only want to retrieve the immediate parent, you would need to know its `objectId` or some other unique identifier.
Also note that the `first()` method returns the first match, which could be any parent of `childObj`. If you want to retrieve all matches, you should use the `find()` method instead.
Finally, make sure to replace `'ParentClass'` with the actual class name where the `children` field is defined.
Let me know if you need further assistance!
The provided JavaScript code uses the Parse.com SDK to perform a query on the `ParentClass` to find all objects that contain the specified `childObj` in their `children` field.
1. We create a new instance of `Parse.Query` for the `ParentClass`.
2. We set up the query to look for objects where the value of the `children` field is equal to the `childObj` object using `query.equalTo('children', childObj)`.
3. We then call `first()` on the query to execute it and retrieve the first matching object.

4. The `success` callback function is called when the query completes successfully, passing the matched parent object as an argument. We can then access the parent object's attributes using the `get()` method.
5. The `error` callback function is called if the query encounters an error.

how to execute jquery functions in a order?,"<blockquote>
""I know we can establish many event handler via addEventListener, but the order of their execution isn't guaranteed.""

Order of execution isn't guaranteed for event handlers bound with addEventListener(), but order of execution definitely is guaranteed for event handlers bound with jQuery. jQuery calls your handlers in the same order they were bound.
This isn't made very obvious in giant bold text in the jQuery documentation, but it is there if you look hard enough. From the .on() method doco:
(Event handlers bound to an element are called in the same order that they were bound.)
Or in more detail from the .bind() method

When an event reaches an element, all handlers bound to that event type for the element are fired. If there are multiple handlers registered, they will always execute in the order in which they were bound. After all handlers have executed, the event continues along the normal event propagation path.
,What are the methods for sequencing the execution of jQuery functions?,
What are the methods for sequencing the execution of jQuery functions?

jQuery has a thing called a Deffered object -- it lets you set up a series of callbacks to run in sequence, and then run a bit of code once everything is wrapped up. Check out the dox: http://api.jquery.com/category/deferred-object/ (http://api.jquery.com/category/deferred-object/)

In the current version of jQuery, it's all handled with the ""Deferred"" mechanism. The readiness of the page is encapsulated in a Deferred object, and functions are simply added to the ""done()"" queue. The Deferred API simply remembers whether the page is ready or not, so passing in a function as a ""ready"" handler after the page is ready will simply call the function immediately. The code to keep track of when ""ready"" actually happens is pretty tortured, however.
If the code needs to be executed in order, then they should in the same dom ready callback function, otherwise, you could divide them into different dom ready callback.

I've found using a ""deferred"" works pretty nicely for this kind of stuff. They allow you to easily define a list of actions that should execute, and a callback / list of callbacks. I believe they introduced a jQuery deferred object (http://api.jquery.com/category/deferred-object/) in jQuery 1.5

Many ways to do this. One way could be add them on a queue, where this queue can do only thing at a time. In each function, when its done dequeue it so the next function can run. You could use jquery's queue function: http://api.jquery.com/jquery.queue/ (http://api.jquery.com/jquery.queue/)
Have a look at using jQuery $.Deferred()
column2: (http://api.jquery.com/deferred.then/) That can allow you to run each function in sequence, one waiting after the other. For example: var a = function() { var defer = $.Deferred()
column5: // When this fires, the code in a().then(/..../)
column23: means you can control when the function yields execution to the next function.

column1: There are four ways I can think of: Manage the callbacks yourself, and only have one event handler that calls the functions in the desired order. In the function that is supposed to fired last, do the actual work in a zero-millisecond timeout. If all other functions work synchronously (and you can live with the final one not happening during the event bubbling), this will achieve the same thing. Bind the to-be-fired-last handler higher up in the DOM tree. You'll have to test if that works with submit events
column2: bubbling of these events doesn't work in IE, but the jQuery docs (http://api.jquery.com/submit/) mention that this has been normalized in jQuery. May be worth a try. Somewhat similar to 1., when binding any other handler than the low-priority one, unbind the latter, bind the new one, and finally re-bind the last-to-be-run.

column1: Please provide your best answer below:

The problem requires finding a method for sequencing the execution of jQuery functions. This involves ensuring that functions are executed in a specific order, without interfering with each other's execution.
Based on the given context, several methods can be used to sequence the execution of jQuery functions. These include:
- Managing callbacks manually and having a single event handler that calls the functions in the desired order.
- Binding the last function to be fired in a higher position in the DOM tree.
- Using jQuery's Deferred object to create a queue of actions that should be executed in sequence.
- Utilizing the jQuery queue function to manage a queue of functions.
## Step 3: Evaluating the Deferred object solution

Using the Deferred object seems like a promising approach. It allows creating a list of actions that should be executed in sequence and provides a callback or list of callbacks. This ensures that each function is executed only after the previous one has completed.
## Step 4: Choosing the most suitable solution
Considering the requirements and the available options, using the Deferred object appears to be the most efficient and reliable method for sequencing the execution of jQuery functions.

Compiling a typescript project with webpack,"

Webpack itself won't do that for you. You will need to write litter helper function to achieve this. The basic idea is to crawl the directory, find all the files and then provide them to Webpack:
// Recursively find all the `.ts` files inside src folder.
// fileKey is relative filename without extension.
// Use the entry object generated above.
,Building a TypeScript application using Webpack for compilation,
Building a TypeScript application using Webpack for compilation

You can install the TypeScript compiler and the TypeScript loader from npm by running: npm install --save-dev typescript ts-loader tsconfig.json: { ""compilerOptions"": { ""outDir"": ""./dist/"", ""sourceMap"": true, ""noImplicitAny"": true, ""module"": ""commonjs"", ""target"": ""es5"", ""jsx"": ""react"", ""allowJs"": true } } webpack.config.js . A basic webpack with TypeScript config should look along these lines: module.exports = { entry: './index.ts', output: { filename: 'bundle.js', path: __dirname }, module: { rules: [ { test: /\.tsx?$/, loader: 'ts-loader', exclude: /node_modules/, } ] }, resolve: { extensions: ["".tsx"", "".ts"", "".js""] } }

You are probably compiling down to the commonJS module format (check your tsconfig.json) That means it generates require function calls for you and it is your responsibility to provide a commonjs loader. You also probably want to bundle all your files into one. It just so happens that webpack does both and is very often used together with typescript :)

I found a solution by using webpack's resolve alias: https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/ (https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/) in conjunction with tsconfig.json (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html)). I needed to specify a baseUrl and paths to match what I have setup in my resolve alias.

Use webpack (https://webpack.js.org/) with ts-loader (https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader) to compile TypeScript and create a single bundle: Install webpack > npm install webpack ts-loader --save-dev Create webpack.config.js const path = require('path')
column2: module.exports = { entry: ""./src/index.ts"", output: { filename: ""bundle.js"", path: path.resolve(__dirname, 'dist') }, resolve: { extensions: ["".webpack.js"", "".web.js"", "".ts"", "".js""] }, module: { rules: [{ test: /\.ts$/, loader: ""ts-loader"" }] } } Run webpack > webpack You may also need to install webpack-cli (messages will tell you as you go to run the webpack command) > npm install webpack-cli See the documentation on webpack and ts-loader for more as configuration options change over time.

column1: Assuming this is for a typescript project (by the tags of this question), this seems like configuration issue that needs to be addressed by having correct setup on your package.json and webpack config file. It would be helpful if you can share what's in your package.json, but I think looking at the npm script hooks (https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/scripts) and trying to properly linking the hooks with the webpack build cli script would be a good starting point for solving your problem. I suggest you to make sure: Webpack build process(or whatever method you use for typescript compilation) is linked with the hook(s) that are triggered after npm install on your local, which is automatically ran when someone installs your package through npm install The compiled javascript bundle is exposed correctly through your package.json as minimum, you may need to check if you need to actually compile your typescript sources, depending on if you are only supporting typescript or not. This is off topic, but do not use webpack unless you really do need to use webpack. Oftentimes it is just enough to use typescript compiler itself if you are writing a npm module.

Try to set ""allowJs"": false Or to exclude the webpack config file from the typescript compiler using exclude https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html)

So I finally succeeded to make it work. I was missing a proper declaration of my types in the library's package.json, this is how it look now, and it works :) { ""name"": ""myWebpackTypescriptLib"", ""version"": ""0.0.1"", ""description"": ""A webpack typescript library, usable in browser, node and other typescript projects."", ""main"": ""dist/index.node.js"", ""types"": ""dist/ts/index.d.ts"", // <---- this here was not properly set, it gives access to the typescript definitions when importing from other typescripts files ""scripts"": { ""test"": ""echo \""Error: no test specified\"" && exit 1"", ""build"": ""webpack --mode=development --progress --config webpack.config.js"", ""prod"": ""webpack --mode=production --progress --config webpack.config.js"" }, ... }

And tsc should create a javascript (myfile.js) and definition file (myfile.d.ts) in the ./build location. TypeScript is not nicely modeled to handle bundling. That is something you should use some other tool to do More e.g. Webpack quickstart: https://basarat.gitbooks.io/typescript/content/docs/quick/browser.html (https://basarat.gitbooks.io/typescript/content/docs/quick/browser.html) Don't recommend out / outFile : https://basarat.gitbooks.io/typescript/content/docs/tips/outFile.html (https://basarat.gitbooks.io/typescript/content/docs/tips/outFile.html)

Generally, you write typescript in your src directory, create a tsconfig.json (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html) file with your compiler settings, and then use tsc (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to compile into javascript on another directory. I have recently created a basic typescript starter project (https://github.com/lucascaro/ts-node-starter) in github that you can check for reference. In the tsconfig.json you can see that the code goes into the src directory, and the generated javascript goes into dist. This repository uses tsc to compile via npm run build, but you can also use webpack (https://webpack.js.org/guides/typescript/), especially if you are compiling a project with multiple files for web, or if you want to use other transpilers like babel, etc. example tsconfig.json { ""compilerOptions"": { ""module"": ""commonjs"", ""target"": ""es2018"", ""sourceMap"": true, ""outDir"": ""dist"", ""strict"": true, }, ""include"": [ ""src/**/*.ts"" ], ""exclude"": [ ""node_modules"", ""**/node_modules/*"" ] } In your project In your specific use case, you are using webpack to transpile source files into javascript. Your webpack.config.js tells webpack how to do it. It is generating main.js in your dist directory (see entries in your config, and documentation for entry points (https://webpack.js.org/concepts/entry-points/)). If what you want is to add a new file into the existing project then you will need to add a new entry: module.exports = { entry: { main: './ClientApp/boot.tsx', webGL: './ClientApp/webGL.tsx' } }
column2: this tells webpack to build 2 separate files with all dependencies bundled in each of them, one for your main app, and one for your webGL file.
